description: Strand units: Representing and interpreting data

teaching.topicContent: Introduce the concept of data representation and its importance.Explain how data can be collected, organized, and represented in different formats. Show examples of various data representations like pictograms, bar charts, and pie charts.

teaching.topicTitle: Creating Pictograms and Single Bar Charts
teaching.topicContent: Teach students how to collect data and represent it using pictograms and single bar charts.   Provide real-world scenarios for data collection, such as favorite colors or pets.Guide students in creating accurate and informative representations.

Introduce multiple bar charts to represent data with multiple categories.Teach students about the mode, the most frequently occurring item in a data set. Have students collect and represent data using multiple bar charts and identify modes.

Introduce pie charts as a way to represent data as proportions of a whole. Teach students how to create and interpret simple pie charts.Provide examples and discuss the significance of each sector in a pie chart..

Present class-based examples of pictograms, bar charts, and pie charts.Engage students in discussions about interpreting charts.Show charts from newspapers, magazines, and computer-generated sources and guide interpretation.

Teach students how to compile data sets from various sources.  Guide them in compiling lists of statistics from personal experiences and scenarios.Show how compiled data sets can be used for representation, interpretation, and problem-solving.

Explain the concept of averages and their relevance in data analysis.  Teach students how to calculate averages by adding values and dividing by the number of items. Provide examples of calculating averages from data sets.

teaching.topicTitle: Using Data Sets to Solve Problems
teaching.topicContent: Present real-world problems based on data sets.Challenge students to use the data representations and calculations they've learned to solve these problems.Encourage critical thinking and application of data analysis skills.

teaching.topicTitle: Identifying Possible Outcomes of Random Processes
teaching.topicContent: Introduce the concept of possible outcomes in random processes.Engage students in discussions and list all possible outcomes of rolling a die, tossing two coins, and drawing cubes from a bag.

Present scenarios where probability plays a role, such as games of chance.Teach students to calculate probabilities based on the number of possible outcomes.Encourage students to apply their understanding of probability to analyze real-life situations.

test.description: Put your Swift knowledge to the test.

questions.content: In a pictogram, each symbol represents 3 items. If the pictogram shows 12 symbols, how many items do they represent in total?
You have a data set of test scores: 85, 92, 77, 95, and 77. What is the mode of the data?
A pie chart represents the favorite fruits of a class. If 25% of the class chose apples, how many students chose apples if there are 40 students in total?
You have a bar chart that shows the number of books read by students. The bars represent 5 books, and one bar is 15 units long. How many books did the student read?
If the average age of a group of friends is 10 years, and there are 5 friends, what is the total age of all friends combined?
You have a data set of test scores: 85, 92, 78, 95, and 88. What is the range of the data?
In a bar chart, one bar represents 12 units. If a bar is 48 units long, what does it represent?
If you roll a number cube and flip a coin, how many equally likely outcomes are possible?
A spinner is divided into 8 equal sections. Three sections are labeled 'Win.' What is the probability of landing on 'Win'?
You have a data set of ages: 9, 12, 11, 10, and 13. What is the median age?
You flipped a coin 30 times, and it landed on heads 18 times. What is the experimental probability of landing on heads?
You have a data set of favorite colors: red, blue, green, red, and yellow. What is the mode of the data?
You have a pie chart that represents the favorite ice cream flavors. If the 'Chocolate' sector covers 45Â°, what percentage of students chose chocolate?
In a data set of test scores, the lowest score is 65 and the highest score is 92. What is the range of the scores?
You have a bar chart that shows the number of hours students spent studying. If a bar represents 4 hours, and one bar is 16 units long, how many hours did the student study?
You have a data set of favorite colors: red, blue, green, red, and yellow. What is the median of the data?
If you flip a coin and roll a number cube, how many equally likely outcomes are possible?
A spinner is divided into 10 equal sections. Four sections are labeled 'Yes.' What is the probability of landing on 'Yes'?
You have a data set of ages: 9, 11, 11, 10, and 13. What is the mode of the ages?
You have a data set of test scores: 85, 92, 78, 95, and 88. What is the mean (average) of the data?
A pie chart represents the favorite fruits of a class. If the 'Banana' sector covers 36Â°, what percentage of students chose bananas?
In a bar chart, one bar represents 8 units. If a bar is 40 units long, what does it represent?
If you roll a number cube twice, how many equally likely outcomes are possible?
You have a data set of favorite subjects: Maths, Science, Art, Maths, and History. What is the mode of the data?
A spinner is divided into 6 equal sections. Two sections are labeled 'Red.' What is the probability of landing on 'Red'?
You have a data set of ages: 9, 12, 11, 10, and 13. What is the range of the ages?

You have a bar chart that shows the number of hours students spent on different activities. The bars represent 2 hours each. If a bar is 10 units long, how many hours did the student spend on that activity?
If you flip a coin three times, how many equally likely outcomes are possible?
You have a data set of favorite animals: Dog, Cat, Dog, Fish, and Bird. What is the mode of the data?
You have a pie chart that represents the favorite seasons. If the 'Summer' sector covers 72Â°, what percentage of students prefer summer?
If you roll a number cube and spin a spinner divided into 4 equal sections, how many equally likely outcomes are possible?
You have a data set of test scores: 85, 92, 78, 95, and 88. What is the median of the data?
In a bar chart, one bar represents 6 units. If a bar is 30 units long, what does it represent?
You have a data set of favorite colors: blue, green, blue, red, and yellow. What is the mode of the data?
If you flip two coins, how many equally likely outcomes are possible?
You have a spinner divided into 12 equal sections. Three sections are labeled 'Yes.' What is the probability of landing on 'Yes'?
A class of 28 students voted for their favorite subject. 8 students chose Math, 10 chose Science, and the rest chose History. What percentage of students chose History?
You have a data set of ages: 9, 12, 11, 10, and 13. What is the mean (average) of the ages?
In a bar chart, one bar represents 5 units. If a bar is 25 units long, what does it represent?
You have a data set of favorite ice cream flavors: Vanilla, Chocolate, Strawberry, and Vanilla. What is the mode of the data?
A spinner is divided into 8 equal sections. If three sections are labeled 'Blue,' what is the probability of landing on 'Blue'?
You have a bar chart that shows the number of books read by students. The bars represent 5 books each. If a bar is 15 units long, how many books did the student read?
If you flip two coins and roll a number cube, how many equally likely outcomes are possible?
A pie chart represents the favorite subjects of a class. If the 'Math' sector covers 45Â°, what percentage of students chose Math?
You have a data set of heights (in cm): 120, 132, 138, 125, and 130. What is the range of the heights?
If you roll a number cube and flip a coin, how many equally likely outcomes are possible?
You have a data set of favorite animals: Cat, Dog, Fish, and Cat. What is the mode of the data?
A spinner is divided into 10 equal sections. If two sections are labeled 'Green,' what is the probability of not landing on 'Green'?
You have a data set of test scores: 78, 85, 90, 88, and 92. What is the median of the data?
In a bar chart, one bar represents 7 units. If a bar is 42 units long, what does it represent?
You have a pie chart that represents the favorite sports of a class. If the 'Soccer' sector covers 135Â°, what percentage of students chose soccer?
You have a data set of ages: 8, 10, 9, 11, and 12. What is the mean (average) of the ages?
You have a data set of favorite colors: red, green, blue, and red. What is the mode of the data?
You have a data set of favorite animals: Dog, Cat, Fish, Bird, and Dog. What is the mode of the data?
If you roll a number cube and flip a coin, how many equally likely outcomes are possible?
A spinner is divided into 5 equal sections. If one section is labeled 'Orange,' what is the probability of not landing on 'Orange'?
You have a bar chart that shows the number of apples collected by students. The bars represent 10 apples each. If a bar is 30 units long, how many apples did the student collect?
You have a pie chart that represents the favorite pizza toppings of a class. If the 'Pepperoni' sector covers 72Â°, what percentage of students chose pepperoni?
You have a data set of the heights (in cm) of five students: 130, 142, 138, 125, and 130. What is the range of the heights?
A spinner is divided into 6 equal sections. If two sections are labeled 'Blue,' what is the probability of landing on 'Blue'?
You have a bar chart that shows the number of books read by students. The bars represent 8 books each. If a bar is 40 units long, how many books did the student read?

You have a data set of favorite animals: Dog, Parrot, Dog, Fish, and Cat. What is the mode of the data?
A spinner is divided into 8 equal sections. If three sections are labeled 'Green,' what is the probability of landing on 'Green'?
You have a data set of ages: 10, 12, 11, 13, and 12. What is the mode of the ages?
You have a pie chart that represents the favorite sports of a class. If the 'Soccer' sector covers 144Â°, what percentage of students chose soccer?
If you roll a dice two times, how many equally likely outcomes are possible?
